questions.text: A child presents with continuing seizures for the past 30 minutes. The relatives say that there had been no seizure-free intervals in the past 30 minutes. After stabilizing the vitals, what is the first drug that should be administered?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A- Diazepam

Management of Status Epilepticus:

Status epilepticus is a medical emergency characterized by continuous seizure activity or recurrent seizures without recovery of consciousness between episodes. The definition has evolved to recognize the importance of early intervention:

  • Traditional definition: seizures lasting >30 minutes

  • Current definition: continuous seizures lasting ≥5 minutes, or two or more seizures without full recovery between them

Early intervention is critical as neuronal damage can begin to occur after 5-30 minutes of continuous seizure activity.

Initial Assessment and Stabilization (0-5 minutes)

  1. Stabilize airway, breathing, and circulation

    • Position patient appropriately to maintain open airway

    • Assess oxygenation and provide oxygen via nasal cannula/mask

    • Monitor vital signs continuously

    • Consider intubation if respiratory assistance is needed

  2. Initial assessment

    • Perform quick neurological exam if possible

    • Check blood glucose levels (treat if <60 mg/dl)

    • Secure IV access

  3. Laboratory tests to obtain

    • Electrolytes, hematology, toxicology screen

    • Anticonvulsant drug levels (if on medication)

First-Line Treatment (5-20 minutes)

 

A benzodiazepine is the initial therapy of choice:

  • Intravenous lorazepam: 0.1 mg/kg up to maximum of 4 mg, may repeat in 5-10 min

  • Intravenous midazolam: 0.2 mg/kg up to 10 mg total dose, may repeat in 5-10 min

  • Intramuscular midazolam: 0.2 mg/kg (if IV access not available)

  • Rectal diazepam: 0.5 mg/kg (if IV access not available)

  • Buccal midazolam: 0.5 mg/kg (if IV access not available)

Second-Line Treatment (20-40 minutes)

 

If seizures continue after benzodiazepine administration, proceed to one of these options:

  • Intravenous fosphenytoin: 20 mg PE/kg loading dose (maximum 1500 mg/dose)

  • Intravenous valproate: 40 mg/kg loading dose (maximum 3000 mg/dose)

  • Intravenous levetiracetam: 30-60 mg/kg loading dose (maximum 4500 mg/dose)

  • Intravenous phenobarbital: 15-20 mg/kg loading dose (if not given initially)

Third-Line Treatment (40-60 minutes)

 

If seizures still continue (refractory status epilepticus):

  • Consider repeating second-line therapy

  • Consider anesthetic doses of:

    • Thiopental

    • Midazolam

    • Pentobarbital

    • Propofol (with caution in children due to propofol infusion syndrome risk)

Continuous EEG monitoring is recommended at this stage.

questions.text: A child presents to the OPD with intracranial diffuse calcifications, chorioretinitis, and hydrocephalus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Congenital T

questions.text: A young child with congenital hydrocephalus was treated with a successful ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt. Four months post-surgical repair, the child presented with fever, nuchal rigidity, and irritability. Suspecting meningitis, which of the following is the next best step of management?

options.label: B
options.text: Check shunt patency by nuclear study

options.label: C
options.text: Blood culture and take CSF sample from shunt tap

options.label: D
options.text: Blood culture and take CSF sample by lumbar puncture

questions.correct_answer: C. Blood culture and take CSF sample from shunt tap
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - Blood culture and take CSF sample from shunt

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a child who exhibits generalized swelling and is diagnosed with high cholesterol levels, as well as protein 3+ and fat bodies observed in urine analysis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Nephrotic Syndrome:

 

Nephrotic syndrome

Nephritic syndrome (Option B)

Clinical Presentation

Edema, heavy proteinuria

Hematuria, oliguria, edema, hypertension

Proteinuria

Heavy (3+ to 4+) on dipstick

(>3.5gm/24 hour)

(1+ to 2+) levels of proteinuria (<1gm/ 24-hour)

Hematuria

Rare, microscopic hematuria may occur

Common, with cola-colored urine due to gross hematuria

Urinary Casts

Hyaline and granular casts

Red blood cell casts (indicating glomerular inflammation)

Serum Albumin

Low (<1 g/dL)

Usually normal unless severe renal impairment

Blood Urea and Creatinine

Normal unless hypovolemia or acute kidney injury

Elevated due to impaired renal function

Serum Complement C3

Normal

Low in 90% of cases, returns to normal in 8-12 weeks

Cholesterol

Hypercholesterolemia (may cause milky plasma)

No significant hypercholesterolemia

ASO/Anti-DNase B Titers

Not elevated

Elevated ASO titers (pharyngitis) or anti-DNase B (skin infection)

Nephrotic syndrome

Nephritic syndrome
  • Massive proteinuria
  • Lipiduria
  • Hypoalbuminemia
  • Edema
  • Thrombotic events
  • Mild proteinuria
  • Hypertension
  • Oliguria
  • Hematuria
  • Azotemia

questions.text: In a child presenting with febrile seizures, which is the first-line drug used to control the seizures?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - M

questions.text: A newborn infant is brought to the pediatric clinic due to the presence of a sac-like protrusion on the lower back. The protrusion is covered by a thin membrane and contains spinal cord tissue and nerves. The infant's lower limbs exhibit weakness and impaired sensation. The mother reports inadequate prenatal folic acid intake during pregnancy. Which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - Spina bifida

Category

Details

Definition

Failure of proper closure of neural tube & covering mesoderm/ectoderm; most common congenital CNS anomaly.

Inheritance

Primary NTDs have multifactorial inheritance.

Maternal risk factors

Alcohol, radiation exposure, IDDM, valproate, carbamazepine, zinc and folate deficiency.

Types of NTDs

Spina bifida occulta, meningocele, encephalocele, myelomeningocele, anencephaly, caudal regression syndrome, dermal sinus, tethered cord, syringomyelia, diastematomyelia, lipoma, iniencephaly.

Spina bifida occulta

Midline defect of vertebral bodies without protrusion of spinal cord or meninges; usually asymptomatic and not of consequence.

Craniorachischisis

Rare malformation with skull and spinal bone defects; brain and nerves exposed; may have other defects like imperforate anus.

Meningocele

Meninges herniate through vertebral arches or sacrum; spinal cord normal. Fluctuant midline mass that may transilluminate. Surgery may be delayed in asymptomatic cases with normal neuro findings and skin covering.

Myelomeningocele

Most common in lumbosacral region; sac-like cystic structure with neural tissue; 80% develop hydrocephalus with type II Chiari malformation.

Anencephaly

Large defect of calvarium, meninges, and scalp; associated with rudimentary brain due to failure of closure of rostral neuropore.

Iniencephaly

Retroflexion of head with occipital and upper spine defects, nearly absent neck; defect can range from acrania to minimal defect.

Prenatal diagnosis

Detailed ultrasound, MSAFP (maternal serum α-fetoprotein), amniotic fluid acetylcholinesterase (AChE).

Prevention

0.4 mg folic acid daily for all women of childbearing age; 4 mg daily for high-risk women (prior affected child).

Risk of recurrence

3-4% after 1 affected child; 10% after 2 affected children.

Treatment

Surgery for defect; VP shunt if hydrocephalus present. Open lesions should be closed within 24 hours. Antibiotics if infection is present.

questions.text: Steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome is defined as failure to achieve remission after ___ weeks when on a daily corticosteroid therapy regimen.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - 6

questions.text: Which of the following increase the risk of recurrence of febrile seizures? Age <1 year Temperature of 38-39°C Duration of fever <24 h Duration of fever >48 h
questions.explanation:
Major Risk Factors
  • Age <1 yr (1)
  • Duration of fever < 24 hr (3)
  • Fever 38-39°C (100.4-102.2°F) (2)

Minor Risk Factors
  • Family history of febrile seizures
  • Family history of epilepsy
  • Complex febrile seizure
  • Daycare
  • Male gender
  • Lower serum sodium at time of presentation

Simple Febrile Seizure

Complex Febrile Seizure
  • Generalised tonic-clonic seizure.
  • Lasts ≤15 minutes.
  • No recurrence within 24 hours.
  • Quick recovery to baseline without deficit.
  • Lasts >15 minutes.
  • It may be focal in nature.
  • It may recur within 24 hours.

Common between 6-60 months, benign, and does not require extensive workup.

Higher risk of recurrence, and it requires further evaluation.

questions.text: How would you manage a child with status epilepticus? Airway and breathing IV Lorazepam Midazolam, Propofol, Thiopentone IV Fosphenytoin
Adrenocorticotropic hormone is the drug of choice in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
West Syndrome

Age group

Typically occurs between 2 and 12 months of age.

Genetics

ARX Gene Mutations: In males, linked to ambiguous genitalia and cortical migration abnormalities.

Types
  • Cryptogenic (Unknown Etiology): Normal development before onset.
  • Symptomatic: Associated with developmental delays due to perinatal issues, brain malformations, metabolic disorders, or other causes.

Clinical Features
  • Infantile Epileptic Spasms: Clusters of spasms occurring mainly during drowsiness or upon waking.
  • Developmental Regression
  • Hypsarrhythmia on EEG: A chaotic, high-voltage background with multifocal spikes.

Management

First-Line Treatment: Hormonal therapy, primarily ACTH (80 mg/mL)

  • Dosage: 150 units/m² daily (75 units/m² twice daily) for 2 weeks, then taper gradually.
  • Monitoring: EEGs at 1, 2, and 4 weeks to assess response.
  • Early intervention is crucial, as a delay beyond 3 weeks can worsen the prognosis.

Alternative Treatments
  • Oral Prednisolone: Lower-cost alternative (Less effective)
  • Vigabatrin: Used as a first-line agent in West syndrome associated with tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) or second-line if hormonal therapy fails. Side effects include retinal toxicity.
  • Ketogenic Diet: Considered a third-line therapy.
  • Other Medications: Valproate, benzodiazepines (nitrazepam, clonazepam), topiramate, lamotrigine, zonisamide, pyridoxine, and IVIG. These drugs can help reduce seizure frequency and severity but are not uniformly effective and may be used alongside ACTH or vigabatrin in cases with incomplete response.

Side Effects and Precautions
  • Side Effects of Hormonal Therapy: Hypertension, electrolyte imbalance, infections, hyperglycemia, and gastric ulcers.
  • Vaccination: Live vaccines are contraindicated, and other vaccines may be ineffective during and shortly after hormonal therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the given image?

options.label: C
options.text: It is associated with facial angiofibroma

options.label: D
options.text: They are diagnostic of a neurocutaneous syndrome

questions.correct_answer: C. It is associated with facial angiofibroma
questions.explanation:
Feature

Description

Café-au-lait macules (CALMs)

>5 mm in prepubertal, >15 mm in postpubertal.

6 or more needed for diagnosis

Axillary/Inguinal Freckling

Multiple hyperpigmented areas, 2-3 mm in diameter.

Iris Lisch Nodules (Option D)

Hamartomas in the iris (Option A), best seen with a slit-lamp.

2 or more needed for diagnosis and doesn’t cause any visual disturbances. (Option B)

Neurofibromas

Two or more neurofibromas or one plexiform neurofibroma.

Osseous Lesion

Sphenoid dysplasia (which may cause pulsating exophthalmos) or cortical thinning of long bones with or without pseudoarthrosis (most often the tibia).

Optic Gliomas

CNS tumor affecting the optic nerve.

Family History

First-degree relative with an NF1 diagnosis based on these criteria.

questions.explanation: Correct Option D - Multicystic Enceph

questions.text: Anencephaly occurs due to the inability of the neural tube to close at which week of intrauterine life?
What is the most common cause of seizures in a 2-year-old child ?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Febrile seizu

questions.text: What is the most likely reason for an 8-month-old baby being brought to the hospital with issues of inadequate feeding and unusual spasms in the lower limb, along with symptoms of fever, bulging fontanelle, and lethargy ?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Mening

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic of cerebral palsy ?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Microceph

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect in relation to the provided image ?

options.label: C
options.text: It is associated with facial angiofibroma

options.label: D
options.text: They are diagnostic of a neurocutaneous syndrome

questions.correct_answer: C. It is associated with facial angiofibroma
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - It is associated with facial ang

Inheritance

Autosomal dominance

Genes involved
  • NF-1 gene on chromosome 17
  • NF-2 gene on chromosome 22

Diagnostic criteria for neurofibromatosis - 1

Presence of 2 or more of the following:

  • Freckling of the axillary or inguinal areas
  • Lisch nodules, 2 or more involving the eyes
  • Optic glioma (most common tumor seen in NF-1)
  • First-degree relative affected with same disorder
  • Presence of 2 or more neurofibromas
  • Presence of 6 or more Caif au lait spots - Significant if the size is >5 mm in prepubertal age and >15 mm in Adolescence
  • A distinctive osseous lesion, such as sphenoid dysplasia or thinning of long bone cortex, also known as dysplasia of the sphenoidal and tibial bone.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a newborn who has a patch of hair on the lower back region ?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A

questions.text: Which of the following is not part of the criteria for diagnosing neurofibromatosis 1 ?

options.label: C
options.text: Dysplasia of the sphenoidal and tibial bone

questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Acoustic neu

questions.text: What is the recommended duration for isolating a child after diagnosis of bacterial meningitis in order to prevent further transmission ?
questions.correct_answer: A. Till 24 hours after starting antibiotics
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Till 24 hours after starting

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for an adolescent girl who experiences instances of dropping objects from her hands, particularly in the morning and during exams, without any history of loss of consciousness with EEG showing signs of epileptic spikes ?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Juv
